Description: Head of M. Antonius right, bearded; before, inscription; behind, inscription. Border of dots. (obverse)
Mars standing facing, wearing helmet and holding spear in right hand and sword in scabbard in left hand; on left, inscription; on right, inscription. Border of dots. (reverse)
State: Associated with: Roman Republic Ancient Greece and Rome: Roman Republic
Curator's comments: Produced at Rome, this portrait of Antony is in a fine, monumental style. The legend gives him his official title 'IIIVIR R[ei] P[u]ublicae C[onstituendae]' (Member of the Board of Three for Establishing the Commonwealth). The Three, Antony, Octavian, and Lepidus, were by law effectively given supreme authority over the Roman state.
Bibliographic references: RR1 / Coins of the Roman Republic in the British Museum: vol. 1 aes rude, aes signatum, aes grave, and coinage of Rome from B.C. 268. (4278, p.584)
Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (236)
Ghey, Leins & Crawford 2010 / A catalogue of the Roman Republican Coins in the British Museum, with descriptions and chronology based on M.H. Crawford, Roman Republican Coinage (1974) (494.17.1)
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Mark Antony
